title: Paneer Besan Chilla
ingredients: 1 teaspoon olive oil or ghee for cooking
steps: In a bowl, mix besan, salt, cumin powder, and turmeric powder.
Add water gradually to make a smooth batter of pouring consistency.
Add grated paneer, chopped onions, tomatoes, green chilies, and coriander leaves. Mix well.
Heat a non- stick pan and spread a little oil.
Pour a ladleful of batter and spread it in a circular motion to make a thin chilla.
Cook on medium heat until the edges start to leave the pan.
Flip and cook the other side until golden brown.
Serve hot with mint chutney or a small bowl of yogurt.
nutritionalBenefits: High in protein from paneer and besan, provides complex carbohydrates, and contains essential vitamins and minerals from vegetables.

title: Vegetable Oats Upma
ingredients: 1/4 cup mixed vegetables (carrots, peas, beans), finely chopped
steps: Dry roast the oats for 2-3 minutes and keep aside.
Heat oil in a pan, add mustard seeds and cumin seeds.
When they splutter, add curry leaves, green chili, and ginger. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add onions and sauté until translucent.
Add chopped vegetables, turmeric powder, and salt. Cook for 2-3 minutes.
Add water and bring to a boil.
Add roasted oats and mix well. Cook on low heat for 2-3 minutes.
Garnish with chopped coriander leaves and roasted peanuts.
Serve hot.
nutritionalBenefits: Good source of fiber and complex carbohydrates from oats, protein from peanuts, and vitamins and minerals from vegetables.

title: Ragi Idli
ingredients: 1 cup urad dal (split black gram), soaked for 4 hours
1 tablespoon fenugreek seeds, soaked with urad dal
steps: Grind soaked urad dal and fenugreek seeds to a smooth paste.
Soak poha for 10 minutes and grind to a paste.
Mix ragi flour, rice flour, urad dal paste, poha paste, and salt in a large bowl.
Add water if needed to make a thick batter.
Ferment the batter for 8 hours or overnight.
Grease idli molds and pour the batter.
Steam for 10-12 minutes.
Serve hot with sambar and coconut chutney.
nutritionalBenefits: Rich in calcium and iron from ragi, protein from urad dal, and complex carbohydrates. Good for muscle health and weight management.

title: Pesarattu (Green Moong Dal Dosa)
ingredients: 1 cup green moong dal, soaked for 4-6 hours
1 teaspoon olive oil or ghee for cooking
steps: Drain the soaked moong dal and grind it with ginger, green chilies, and salt to make a smooth batter.
Add chopped coriander leaves, onions, and cumin seeds to the batter and mix well.
Heat a non-stick pan and spread a little oil.
Pour a ladleful of batter and spread it in a circular motion to make a thin dosa.
Drizzle a few drops of oil around the edges.
Cook until the bottom turns golden brown.
Flip and cook the other side.
Serve hot with ginger chutney or upma.
nutritionalBenefits: High in protein from moong dal, low in calories, and rich in fiber. Good for weight loss and muscle maintenance.

title: Egg White Omelette with Vegetables
steps: Beat egg whites in a bowl until frothy.
Add salt, black pepper, and chopped vegetables. Mix well.
Heat oil in a non-stick pan.
Pour the egg mixture and spread evenly.
Cook on medium heat until the bottom sets.
Flip and cook the other side until lightly browned.
Fold in half and garnish with coriander leaves.
Serve hot with a slice of whole grain toast if desired.
nutritionalBenefits: High in protein from egg whites, low in calories and fat, rich in vitamins and minerals from vegetables.

title: Quinoa Upma
ingredients: 1/4 cup mixed vegetables (carrots, peas, beans), finely chopped
steps: Heat oil in a pan, add mustard seeds and cumin seeds.
When they splutter, add curry leaves, green chili, and ginger. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add onions and sauté until translucent.
Add chopped vegetables, turmeric powder, and salt. Cook for 2-3 minutes.
Add rinsed quinoa and mix well.
Add water and bring to a boil.
Reduce heat, cover, and simmer for 15 minutes until quinoa is cooked and water is absorbed.
Garnish with chopped coriander leaves and roasted peanuts.
Serve hot.
nutritionalBenefits: Complete protein source from quinoa, rich in fiber, vitamins, and minerals. Good for muscle building and weight management.

title: Moong Dal Cheela
ingredients: 1 cup yellow moong dal, soaked for 4 hours
1 teaspoon olive oil or ghee for cooking
steps: Drain the soaked moong dal and grind it to a smooth paste with minimal water.
Add chopped onions, tomatoes, green chilies, coriander leaves, cumin powder, turmeric powder, and salt. Mix well.
Heat a non-stick pan and spread a little oil.
Pour a ladleful of batter and spread it in a circular motion to make a thin cheela.
Cook on medium heat until the edges start to leave the pan.
Flip and cook the other side until golden brown.
Serve hot with mint chutney or a small bowl of yogurt.
nutritionalBenefits: High in protein from moong dal, low in calories, and rich in fiber. Good for weight loss and muscle maintenance.

title: Vegetable Poha
ingredients: 1/4 cup mixed vegetables (carrots, peas, beans), finely chopped
steps: Rinse poha in a colander under running water for a few seconds. Drain well and keep aside.
Heat oil in a pan, add mustard seeds and cumin seeds.
When they splutter, add curry leaves, green chili, and onions. Sauté until onions turn translucent.
Add potatoes (if using) and cook until soft.
Add other vegetables, turmeric powder, and salt. Cook for 2-3 minutes.
Add rinsed poha and mix gently.
Cover and cook on low heat for 2-3 minutes.
Add lemon juice, chopped coriander leaves, and roasted peanuts. Mix well.
Serve hot.
nutritionalBenefits: Good source of complex carbohydrates from poha, protein from peanuts, and vitamins and minerals from vegetables.

title: Oats Idli
steps: Dry roast oats until lightly toasted and grind to a coarse powder.
Dry roast semolina for 2-3 minutes.
Mix ground oats, roasted semolina, yogurt, salt, and water to make a thick batter. Let it rest for 15 minutes.
Heat oil in a small pan, add mustard seeds and cumin seeds.
When they splutter, add curry leaves, green chili, and ginger. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add this tempering to the batter along with chopped onions, grated carrots, and coriander leaves.
Add baking soda and mix well.
Grease idli molds and pour the batter.
Steam for 10-12 minutes.
Serve hot with sambar and coconut chutney.
nutritionalBenefits: High in protein and fiber from oats, probiotics from yogurt, and vitamins and minerals from vegetables.

title: Adai Dosa
ingredients: 1 teaspoon olive oil or ghee for cooking
steps: Soak rice and all dals together for 4-6 hours.
Grind them with red chilies, cumin seeds, and salt to make a coarse batter.
Add chopped onions, coriander leaves, spinach, and asafoetida to the batter and mix well.
Heat a non-stick pan and spread a little oil.
Pour a ladleful of batter and spread it in a circular motion to make a thick dosa.
Drizzle a few drops of oil around the edges.
Cook until the bottom turns golden brown.
Flip and cook the other side.
Serve hot with avocado or yogurt.
nutritionalBenefits: High in protein from mixed dals, complex carbohydrates from rice, and vitamins and minerals from vegetables.

title: Whole Wheat Pancakes with Berries
ingredients: 1 teaspoon olive oil or ghee for cooking
steps: In a bowl, mix whole wheat flour, baking powder, and cinnamon.
In another bowl, beat the egg and add milk, honey, and vanilla extract. Mix well.
Add the wet ingredients to the dry ingredients and mix until just combined.
Heat a non-stick pan and spread a little oil.
Pour a ladleful of batter and cook until bubbles form on the surface.
Flip and cook the other side until golden brown.
Serve hot with mixed berries and a drizzle of honey if desired.
nutritionalBenefits: Complex carbohydrates from whole wheat flour, protein from egg, and antioxidants from berries.

title: Masala Dalia (Broken Wheat Upma)
ingredients: 1/4 cup mixed vegetables (carrots, peas, beans), finely chopped
steps: Dry roast dalia for 2-3 minutes and keep aside.
Heat oil in a pan, add mustard seeds and cumin seeds.
When they splutter, add curry leaves, green chili, and ginger. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add onions and sauté until translucent.
Add chopped vegetables, turmeric powder, and salt. Cook for 2-3 minutes.
Add roasted dalia and mix well.
Add water and bring to a boil.
Reduce heat, cover, and simmer for 10-12 minutes until dalia is cooked and water is absorbed.
Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
Serve hot.
nutritionalBenefits: Good source of complex carbohydrates and fiber from broken wheat, and vitamins and minerals from vegetables.

title: Greek Yogurt Parfait
steps: In a glass or bowl, layer Greek yogurt, mixed berries, granola, and chia seeds.
Drizzle with honey if desired.
Serve immediately or refrigerate for later.
nutritionalBenefits: High in protein from Greek yogurt, antioxidants from berries, and fiber from chia seeds and granola.

title: Sprouts Chaat
steps: Steam the mixed sprouts for 5-7 minutes until tender but not mushy.
In a bowl, mix steamed sprouts, chopped cucumber, tomato, onion, green chili, and coriander leaves.
Add lemon juice, chaat masala, cumin powder, and salt. Mix well.
Serve immediately.
nutritionalBenefits: High in protein from sprouts, low in calories, and rich in fiber, vitamins, and minerals.

title: Dal Tadka with Brown Rice
ingredients: 1 cup mixed vegetables (carrots, beans, cauliflower) for side salad
steps: Wash and soak moong dal for 30 minutes. Drain.
Cook brown rice with 1 cup water and a pinch of salt until done.
Pressure cook dal with turmeric powder, salt, and 2 cups water for 3-4 whistles.
Heat ghee in a pan, add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add ginger, garlic, and green chili. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add onions and sauté until translucent.
Add tomatoes and cook until soft.
Add red chili powder and garam masala. Mix well.
Add cooked dal and simmer for 5 minutes.
Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
Serve hot with brown rice and a side of mixed vegetable salad.
nutritionalBenefits: High in protein from moong dal, complex carbohydrates from brown rice, and fiber from vegetables. Good for sustained energy and muscle recovery.

title: Rajma Masala with Jeera Rice
ingredients: 1 cup mixed vegetables (cucumber, carrots, radish) for side salad
steps: Pressure cook soaked rajma with salt and water for 4-5 whistles until soft.
For jeera rice: Wash brown rice and cook with 1 cup water, a pinch of salt, and 1/2 teaspoon cumin seeds.
Heat ghee in a pan, add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add ginger, garlic, and green chili. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add onions and sauté until translucent.
Add tomato puree and cook until oil separates.
Add turmeric powder,  red chili powder, and garam masala. Mix well.
Add cooked rajma with some of its cooking water. Simmer for 10 minutes.
Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
Serve hot with jeera rice and a side of mixed vegetable salad.
nutritionalBenefits: Rich in protein and fiber from kidney beans, complex carbohydrates from brown rice, and essential vitamins from vegetables. Good for muscle building and weight management.

title: Sambar with Brown Rice
ingredients: 1 cup mixed vegetables (carrots, beans, drumsticks, eggplant)
steps: Wash and soak toor dal for 30 minutes. Cook in a pressure cooker with turmeric powder and water for 3-4 whistles.
Cook brown rice with 1 cup water and a pinch of salt until done.
Cook mixed vegetables with salt and water until tender.
Mix tamarind paste in 1/2 cup warm water and extract the juice.
Mash the cooked dal and add it to the cooked vegetables.
Add tamarind extract, sambar powder, and salt. Mix well and simmer for 5 minutes.
For tempering: Heat ghee in a small pan, add mustard seeds and cumin seeds.
When they splutter, add curry leaves, dry red chilies, and asafoetida.
Pour this tempering over the sambar and mix well.
Serve hot with brown rice and cucumber raita.
nutritionalBenefits: Good source of protein from toor dal, complex carbohydrates from brown rice, and various vitamins and minerals from mixed vegetables. The probiotics in raita aid digestion.

title: Avial with Millet Rice
ingredients: 1 cup mixed vegetables (carrots, beans, raw banana, yam)
steps: Cook foxtail millet with 1 cup water and a pinch of salt until done.
Cut all vegetables into 2-inch long pieces.
Cook vegetables with turmeric powder, salt, and  1/2 cup water until tender but not mushy.
Grind coconut, green chili, and cumin seeds to a coarse paste.
Add this paste to the cooked vegetables and mix well.
Beat yogurt until smooth and add it to the vegetables. Mix gently on low heat.
Add curry leaves and coconut oil. Mix well and remove from heat.
Serve hot with millet rice and beetroot pachadi.
nutritionalBenefits: Rich in fiber and micronutrients from mixed vegetables, protein from yogurt, and complex carbohydrates from millet. Good for gut health and sustained energy.

title: Quinoa Bowl with Roasted Vegetables and Paneer
ingredients: 1 cup mixed vegetables (bell peppers, zucchini, broccoli)
steps: Rinse quinoa thoroughly and cook with 1 cup water and a pinch of salt until fluffy.
Toss mixed vegetables with 1/2 tablespoon olive oil, salt, and black pepper.
Roast vegetables in an oven at 200°C for 15-20 minutes or sauté in a pan until tender.
Heat remaining olive oil in a pan, add cubed paneer and sauté until golden brown.
Add cumin powder, coriander powder, and turmeric powder to the paneer. Mix well.
In a bowl, layer cooked quinoa, roasted vegetables, and spiced paneer.
Drizzle lemon juice and garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
Serve warm.
nutritionalBenefits: Complete protein from quinoa and paneer, fiber from vegetables, and essential fatty acids from olive oil. Perfect for muscle building and weight management.

title: Chickpea and Vegetable Stir-Fry with Brown Rice
ingredients: 1 cup mixed vegetables (carrots, bell peppers, green beans)
steps: Cook brown rice with 1 cup water and a pinch of salt until done.
Heat olive oil in a pan, add ginger and garlic. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add onions and sauté until  translucent.
Add mixed vegetables and cook until tender but crisp.
Add cooked chickpeas, cumin powder, coriander powder, turmeric powder, black pepper, and salt. Mix well.
Add soy sauce and mix well. Cook for 2-3 minutes.
Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
Serve hot with brown rice.
nutritionalBenefits: High in protein from chickpeas, complex carbohydrates from brown rice, and fiber from vegetables. Good for muscle recovery and sustained energy.

title: Palak Paneer with Multigrain Roti
steps: For multigrain roti: Mix all flours with salt, add water gradually to make a soft dough. Rest for 15 minutes. Roll into thin rotis and cook on a hot tawa.
Heat ghee in a pan, add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add ginger and garlic. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add onions and sauté until translucent.
Add tomato puree and cook until oil separates.
Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt. Mix well.
Add spinach puree and cook for 3-4 minutes.
Add paneer cubes and garam masala. Mix gently and cook for 2 minutes.
Add fresh cream if using and mix well.
Serve hot with multigrain roti.
nutritionalBenefits: High in protein from paneer, iron and vitamins from spinach, and complex carbohydrates and fiber from multigrain roti. Good for muscle building and overall health.

title: Chana Masala with Steamed Rice
steps: Pressure cook soaked chickpeas with salt and water for 3-4 whistles until soft.
Cook brown rice with 1 cup water and a pinch of salt until done.
Heat ghee in a pan, add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add ginger and garlic. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add onions and sauté until translucent.
Add tomato puree and cook until oil separates.
Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt. Mix well.
Add cooked chickpeas with some of its cooking water. Simmer for 10 minutes.
Add garam masala and amchur powder. Mix well.
Serve hot with brown rice and cucumber-tomato salad.
nutritionalBenefits: Rich in protein and fiber from chickpeas, complex carbohydrates from brown rice, and essential vitamins from salad. Good for muscle building and weight management.

title: Vegetable Poriyal with Rasam and Brown Rice
ingredients: 2 cups mixed vegetables (carrots, beans, cabbage), finely chopped
steps: Cook brown rice with 1 cup water and a pinch of salt until done.
For poriyal: Heat coconut oil in a pan, add mustard seeds and urad dal.
When they splutter, add curry leaves and turmeric powder.
Add chopped vegetables and salt. Mix well.
Cover and cook until vegetables are tender but crisp.
Add grated coconut, mix well, and remove from heat.
For rasam: Extract tamarind juice from tamarind paste using 1 cup warm water.
Boil chopped tomatoes with turmeric powder, salt, and 1 cup water until soft.
Add tamarind extract and rasam powder. Simmer for 5 minutes.
For tempering: Heat ghee in a small pan, add mustard seeds and cumin seeds.
When they splutter, add curry leaves and pour this tempering over the rasam.
Serve poriyal, rasam, and brown rice hot.
nutritionalBenefits: Good source of fiber and micronutrients from vegetables, complex carbohydrates from brown rice, and antioxidants from spices. Light yet nutritious meal.

title: Kara Kuzhambu with Millet Rice
ingredients: 1 cup mixed vegetables (drumstick, brinjal, lady's finger)
steps: Cook foxtail millet with 1 cup water and a pinch of salt until done.
Extract tamarind juice from tamarind paste using 1 cup warm water.
Heat coconut oil in a pan, add mustard seeds and cumin seeds.
When they splutter, add curry leaves and dry red chilies.
Add onions and sauté until translucent.
Add tomatoes and cook until soft.
Add mixed vegetables, turmeric powder, sambar powder, and salt. Mix well.
Add tamarind extract and 1 cup water. Simmer until vegetables are cooked.
Serve hot with millet rice and cucumber raita.
nutritionalBenefits: Rich in fiber and micronutrients from mixed vegetables, protein from yogurt, and complex carbohydrates from millet. Good for gut health and sustained energy.

title: Vegetable Pulao with Raita
ingredients: 1 cup mixed vegetables (carrots, peas, beans, cauliflower)
steps: Wash and soak basmati rice for 30 minutes. Drain.
Heat ghee in a pan, add cumin seeds, cloves, bay leaf, cinnamon, and cardamoms.
Add ginger and garlic. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add onions and sauté until translucent.
Add mixed vegetables, turmeric powder, and salt. Mix well.
Add soaked rice and mix gently.
Add 2 cups water and bring to a boil.
Reduce heat, cover, and cook until rice is done and water is absorbed.
Add garam masala and mix gently.
For raita: Mix yogurt, grated cucumber, roasted cumin powder, and salt.
Serve hot pulao with raita.
nutritionalBenefits: Good source of complex carbohydrates from rice, fiber from vegetables, and protein from yogurt. Perfect for refueling after a workout.

title: Whole Wheat Pasta with Vegetable Sauce
ingredients: 1 cup mixed vegetables (bell peppers, zucchini, broccoli)
steps: Cook whole wheat pasta according to package instructions. Drain and keep aside.
Heat olive oil in a pan, add garlic and sauté for 30 seconds.
Add onions and sauté until translucent.
Add mixed vegetables and cook until tender but crisp.
Add tomato puree, oregano, basil, black pepper, and salt. Simmer for 5-7 minutes.
Add cooked pasta and mix well.
Garnish with grated parmesan cheese if using.
Serve hot with a side of green salad.
nutritionalBenefits: Complex carbohydrates from whole wheat pasta, fiber from vegetables, and healthy fats from olive oil. Good for energy replenishment.

title: Buddha Bowl with Mixed Grains
ingredients: 1 cup mixed vegetables (carrots, bell peppers, cucumber), chopped
steps: Cook quinoa and brown rice separately with water and a pinch of salt until done.
In a bowl, mix olive oil, lemon juice, cumin powder, black pepper, and salt to make a dressing.
In a serving bowl, arrange cooked quinoa, brown rice, chickpeas, mixed vegetables, sprouts, and avocado slices.
Drizzle the dressing over the bowl.
Serve at room temperature.
nutritionalBenefits: Complete protein from quinoa and chickpeas, complex carbohydrates from brown rice, healthy fats from avocado, and fiber from vegetables and sprouts. Balanced and nutrient-dense meal.

title: Lentil Soup with Multigrain Bread
steps: Wash and soak mixed lentils for 30 minutes. Drain.
Heat olive oil in a pan, add garlic and ginger. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add onions and sauté until translucent.
Add mixed vegetables and cook for 2-3 minutes.
Add soaked lentils, turmeric powder, cumin powder, black pepper, salt, and 2 cups water.
Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer until lentils are cooked and soup thickens.
Add lemon juice and chopped coriander leaves.
Serve hot with multigrain bread.
nutritionalBenefits: High in protein from mixed lentils, fiber from vegetables, and complex carbohydrates from multigrain bread. Good for muscle recovery and sustained energy.

title: Mixed Vegetable Curry with Roti
ingredients: 2 cups mixed vegetables (cauliflower, carrots, peas, beans)
steps: For roti: Mix whole wheat flour with salt, add water gradually to make a soft dough. Rest for 15 minutes. Roll into thin rotis and cook on a hot tawa.
Heat oil in a pan, add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add ginger and garlic. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add onions and sauté until translucent.
Add tomato puree and cook until oil separates.
Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, coriander powder, and salt. Mix well.
Add mixed vegetables and 1/2 cup water. Cover and cook until vegetables are tender.
Add garam masala and mix well.
Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
Serve hot with roti.
nutritionalBenefits: Rich in fiber, vitamins, and minerals from mixed vegetables, with complex carbohydrates from whole wheat roti. Light yet nutritious dinner option.

title: Lauki Kofta Curry (Bottle Gourd Dumplings)
ingredients: 2 cups grated bottle gourd (lauki), squeezed to remove water
steps: For koftas: Mix all ingredients for koftas. Shape into small balls.
Bake in a preheated oven at 180°C for 15-20 minutes or shallow fry in a non-stick pan until golden brown.
For curry: Heat oil in a pan, add ginger and garlic. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add onions and sauté until translucent.
Add tomato puree and cook until oil separates.
Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, coriander powder, and salt. Mix well.
Add 1 cup water and bring to a boil.
Add koftas and simmer for 5 minutes.
Add garam masala and mix well.
Prepare rotis as in the previous recipe.
Serve hot kofta curry with roti.
nutritionalBenefits: Low-calorie bottle gourd is rich in fiber and water content, making it ideal for weight loss. Besan adds protein, while whole wheat roti provides complex carbohydrates.

title: Vegetable Stew with Appam
ingredients: 2 cups mixed vegetables (carrots, beans, potatoes, peas)
steps: For appam: Mix rice flour, grated coconut, baking soda, and salt. Add water to make a batter of pouring consistency. Rest for 30 minutes.
Heat an appam pan, pour a ladleful of batter, and swirl to coat the sides. Cover and cook until the edges are crisp and center is soft.
For stew: Heat coconut oil in a pan, add cloves, cinnamon, and cardamoms.
Add onions and curry leaves. Sauté until onions are translucent.
Add mixed vegetables and salt. Mix well.
Add 1 cup water and cook until vegetables are tender.
Add coconut milk and black pepper. Simmer for 5 minutes.
Serve hot stew with appam.
nutritionalBenefits: Light yet nutritious dinner with vegetables providing essential vitamins and minerals. Coconut adds healthy fats, while appam provides necessary carbohydrates.

title: Tomato Rasam with Steamed Vegetables
ingredients: 2 cups mixed steamed vegetables (broccoli, carrots, beans)
steps: Extract tamarind juice from tamarind paste using 1 cup warm water.
Boil chopped tomatoes with turmeric powder, salt, and 1 cup water until soft.
Add  tamarind extract and rasam powder. Simmer for 5 minutes.
For tempering: Heat ghee in a small pan, add mustard seeds and cumin seeds.
When they splutter, add curry leaves and garlic. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Pour this tempering over the rasam.
Steam mixed vegetables with a pinch of salt until tender but crisp.
Serve hot rasam with steamed vegetables and a small portion of brown rice if desired.
nutritionalBenefits: Low-calorie, high-fiber meal with antioxidants from tomatoes and tamarind. Steamed vegetables retain their nutrients, making this a perfect light dinner option.

title: Grilled Paneer and Vegetable Skewers
ingredients: 1 cup mixed vegetables (bell peppers, zucchini, cherry tomatoes, onions), cubed
1/2 cup mint yogurt dip (mint + yogurt + cumin powder)
steps: Mix olive oil, cumin powder, coriander powder, black pepper, red chili powder, lemon juice, and salt to make a marinade.
Toss paneer and vegetables in the marinade and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Thread paneer and vegetables alternately onto skewers.
Grill in an oven at 200°C for 10-15 minutes or cook on a grill pan until charred and tender.
For mint yogurt dip: Blend mint leaves with yogurt, cumin powder, and salt.
Garnish skewers with chopped coriander leaves.
Serve hot with mint yogurt dip and mixed greens salad.
nutritionalBenefits: High in protein from paneer, with fiber and essential nutrients from vegetables. Low-carb dinner option perfect for weight loss and muscle maintenance.

title: Lentil and Vegetable Soup
steps: Wash and soak mixed lentils for 30 minutes. Drain.
Heat olive oil in a pan, add garlic and ginger. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add onions and sauté until translucent.
Add mixed vegetables and cook for 2-3 minutes.
Add soaked lentils, turmeric powder, cumin powder, black pepper, salt, and 2 cups water.
Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer until lentils are cooked and soup thickens.
Add lemon juice and chopped coriander leaves.
Serve hot with a small whole grain bread roll if desired.
nutritionalBenefits: High in protein from lentils, fiber from vegetables, and essential nutrients. A filling yet light dinner option that supports weight loss and muscle recovery.

title: Baingan Bharta (Roasted Eggplant Mash) with Roti
steps: Roast eggplant directly over flame or in an oven until skin is charred and flesh is soft.
Cool, peel, and mash the eggplant.
Heat oil in a pan, add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add ginger and garlic. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add onions and sauté until translucent.
Add tomatoes and cook until soft.
Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt. Mix well.
Add mashed eggplant and cook for 5-7 minutes.
Add garam masala and mix well.
Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
Prepare rotis as in previous recipes.
Serve hot bharta with roti.
nutritionalBenefits: Low-calorie eggplant is rich in fiber and antioxidants, making it ideal for weight loss. Whole wheat roti provides complex carbohydrates for sustained energy.

title: Tinda Masala (Apple Gourd Curry) with Roti
ingredients: 2 cups tinda (apple gourd), peeled and cubed
steps: Heat oil in a pan, add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add ginger and garlic. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add onions and sauté until translucent.
Add tomato puree and cook until oil separates.
Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, coriander powder, and salt. Mix well.
Add tinda cubes and 1/2 cup water. Cover and cook until tinda is tender.
Add garam masala and mix well.
Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
Prepare rotis as in previous recipes.
Serve hot tinda masala with roti.
nutritionalBenefits: Low-calorie tinda is rich in fiber and water content, making it ideal for weight loss. Whole wheat roti provides complex carbohydrates for sustained energy.

title: Vendakkai Poriyal (Okra Stir-Fry) with Rasam
steps: For poriyal: Heat coconut oil in a pan, add mustard seeds and urad dal.
When they splutter, add curry leaves and turmeric powder.
Add chopped onions and sauté until translucent.
Add sliced okra and salt. Mix well.
Cover and cook on low heat until okra is tender but not mushy.
Add grated coconut, mix well, and remove from heat.
For rasam: Follow the rasam recipe from Tuesday.
Serve hot poriyal with rasam and a small portion of brown rice if desired.
nutritionalBenefits: Okra is rich in fiber and low in calories, making it ideal for weight loss. Rasam aids digestion, while a small portion of brown rice provides necessary carbohydrates.

title: Cabbage Thoran with Buttermilk Curry
steps: For thoran: Heat coconut oil in a pan, add mustard seeds and urad dal.
When they splutter, add curry leaves and turmeric powder.
Add chopped onions and sauté until translucent.
Add chopped cabbage and salt. Mix well.
Cover and cook on low heat until cabbage is tender but crisp.
Add grated coconut, mix well, and remove from heat.
For buttermilk curry: Mix buttermilk, grated cucumber, cumin powder, turmeric powder, and salt.
For tempering: Heat coconut oil in a small pan, add mustard seeds and cumin seeds.
When they splutter, add curry leaves and pour this tempering over the buttermilk mixture.
Serve hot thoran with buttermilk curry and a small portion of cooked millet if desired.
nutritionalBenefits: Low-calorie cabbage is rich in fiber and vitamins, while buttermilk provides probiotics and calcium. A light yet nutritious dinner option.

title: Vegetable Khichdi
ingredients: 1 cup mixed vegetables (carrots, peas, beans, cauliflower)
1/2 cup yogurt raita (yogurt + cucumber + cumin powder)
steps: Wash and soak rice and moong dal together for 30 minutes. Drain.
Heat ghee in a pressure cooker, add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add ginger and sauté for 30 seconds.
Add onions and sauté until translucent.
Add mixed vegetables, turmeric powder, and salt. Mix well.
Add soaked rice and moong dal. Mix gently.
Add
5 cups water and pressure cook for 2-3 whistles.
Once pressure releases, open the cooker and add garam masala. Mix gently.
For raita: Mix yogurt, grated cucumber, roasted cumin powder, and salt.
Serve hot khichdi with raita.
nutritionalBenefits: Complete protein from the combination of rice and moong dal, with fiber and nutrients from mixed vegetables. A balanced one-pot meal that's easy to digest.

title: Vegetable Biryani
ingredients: 1 cup mixed vegetables (carrots, peas, beans, cauliflower)
1/2 cup cucumber raita (yogurt + cucumber + cumin powder)
steps: Wash and soak basmati rice for 30 minutes. Drain.
Heat ghee in a pan, add cumin seeds, cloves, bay leaf, cinnamon, and cardamoms.
Add ginger and garlic. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add onions and sauté until golden brown.
Add tomatoes and cook until soft.
Add mixed vegetables, turmeric powder, red chili powder, biryani masala, and salt. Mix well.
Cook for 3-4 minutes.
In a heavy-bottomed pan, layer half of the soaked rice, then the vegetable mixture, and then the remaining rice.
Add 2 cups water, cover with a tight lid, and cook on low heat for 15-20 minutes until rice is done.
Garnish with chopped mint and coriander leaves.
For raita: Mix yogurt, grated cucumber, roasted cumin powder, and salt.
Serve hot biryani with raita.
nutritionalBenefits: Complex carbohydrates from basmati rice, fiber from vegetables, and protein from yogurt. A flavorful and satisfying meal for a flex day.

title: Vegetable Clear Soup with Tofu
ingredients: 1 cup mixed vegetables (carrots, beans, broccoli, mushrooms), finely chopped
steps: Heat olive oil in a pan, add garlic and ginger. Sauté for 30 seconds.
Add onions and sauté until translucent.
Add mixed vegetables and cook for 2-3 minutes.
Add 2 cups water, soy sauce, black pepper, and salt. Bring to a boil.
Reduce heat and simmer until vegetables are tender but crisp.
Add tofu cubes and simmer for 2 more minutes.
Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
Serve hot with a small whole grain bread roll if desired.
nutritionalBenefits: Low-calorie, high-fiber soup with protein from tofu. A light yet nutritious dinner option that's perfect for a prep day.

title: Roasted Vegetable and Chickpea Bowl
ingredients: 1 cup mixed vegetables (bell peppers, zucchini, broccoli), cubed
steps: Preheat oven to 200°C.
Toss mixed vegetables with 1/2 tablespoon olive oil, salt, and black pepper.
Spread on a baking tray and roast for 15-20 minutes until tender and slightly charred.
Heat remaining olive oil in a pan, add garlic and sauté for 30 seconds.
Add cooked chickpeas, cumin powder, coriander powder, and salt. Mix well.
Cook for 2-3 minutes.
In a bowl, arrange roasted vegetables and spiced chickpeas.
Drizzle lemon juice and garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
Serve with a dollop of hummus if desired.
nutritionalBenefits: High in protein from chickpeas, fiber from vegetables, and healthy fats from olive oil. A balanced and satisfying meal that's perfect for a prep day.

title: Greek Yogurt with Berries (Mid-Morning Snacks)
steps: In a bowl, add Greek yogurt.
Top with mixed berries and chia seeds.
Drizzle with honey if desired.
Mix and enjoy.
nutritionalBenefits: Rich in protein from Greek yogurt, antioxidants from berries, and omega-3 fatty acids from chia seeds. Supports muscle recovery and weight management.

title: Paneer Tikka (Mid-Morning Snacks)
steps: Mix yogurt, ginger-garlic paste, red chili powder, cumin powder, garam masala, and salt to make a marinade.
Add paneer cubes, bell peppers, and onions to the marinade. Mix gently.
Marinate for at least 15 minutes.
Thread onto skewers and grill in an oven at 180°C for 10-12 minutes or cook on a non-stick pan until lightly charred.
Sprinkle chaat masala and serve hot.
nutritionalBenefits: High in protein from paneer, low in carbs, and provides essential nutrients from vegetables. Ideal for muscle building and weight management.

title: Sprouts Chaat (Mid-Morning Snacks)
steps: Steam mixed sprouts for 5 minutes until tender but not mushy.
In a bowl, mix steamed sprouts, cucumber, tomato, and onion.
Add chaat masala, cumin powder, salt, and lemon juice. Mix well.
Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
Serve immediately.
nutritionalBenefits: High in protein and fiber from sprouts, low in calories, and rich in vitamins and minerals from fresh vegetables. Perfect for weight loss and muscle maintenance.

title: Vegetable Sandwich (Mid-Morning Snacks)
steps: Spread mint chutney on both slices of bread.
Layer cucumber, tomato, onion, and bell pepper on one slice.
Sprinkle black pepper and salt.
Cover with the other slice of bread.
Toast in a sandwich maker or on a pan until golden brown.
Cut into triangles and serve.
nutritionalBenefits: Complex carbohydrates from whole grain bread, fiber from vegetables, and low in calories. A balanced snack for sustained energy.

title: Fruit and Nut Mix (Mid-Afternoon Snacks)
ingredients: 1/4 cup mixed seasonal fruits (apple, pear, orange), chopped
steps: In a bowl, mix chopped fruits and nuts.
Sprinkle chia seeds and cinnamon powder.
Drizzle honey if desired.
Mix well and enjoy.
nutritionalBenefits: Rich in fiber, vitamins, and minerals from fruits, with healthy fats and protein from nuts. Provides sustained energy and supports overall health.

title: Roasted Makhana (Fox Nuts) (Mid-Afternoon Snacks)
steps: Heat ghee in a pan.
Add makhana and roast on low heat until crisp, stirring continuously.
Add black pepper, cumin powder, and salt. Mix well.
Cool and store in an airtight container.
Enjoy as a crunchy snack.
nutritionalBenefits: Low in calories, high in protein and fiber. A healthy alternative to fried snacks, perfect for weight loss.

title: Cucumber and Carrot Sticks with Hummus (Mid-Afternoon Snacks)
steps: Arrange cucumber and carrot sticks on a plate.
In a small bowl, mix hummus with black pepper and lemon juice.
Serve vegetables with hummus for dipping.
nutritionalBenefits: Low in calories, high in fiber from vegetables, with protein and healthy fats from hummus. A refreshing and satisfying snack.

title: Buttermilk with Spices (Mid-Afternoon Snacks)
steps: Blend yogurt and water until smooth.
Add cumin powder, black salt, black pepper, and grated ginger. Mix well.
Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
Serve chilled.
nutritionalBenefits: Rich in probiotics from yogurt, aids digestion, and provides calcium. A refreshing and hydrating snack.

title: Baked Sweet Potato Wedges (Mid-Afternoon Snacks)
steps: Preheat oven to 200°C.
Wash and cut sweet potato into wedges.
In a bowl, toss sweet potato wedges with olive oil, paprika, garlic powder, and salt.
Arrange on a baking tray and bake for 20-25 minutes until crisp.
Serve hot.
nutritionalBenefits: Rich in complex carbohydrates, fiber, and beta-carotene. A healthier alternative to fried snacks, perfect for post-workout recovery.

title: Oats and Vegetable Cutlet (Mid-Afternoon Snacks)
ingredients: 1/4 cup mixed vegetables (carrots, peas, beans), finely chopped and boiled
steps: Dry roast oats for 2-3 minutes and grind coarsely.
In a bowl, mix ground oats, boiled vegetables, mashed potato, besan, cumin powder, garam masala, coriander leaves, and salt.
Shape into small cutlets.
Heat a non-stick pan and spread a little oil.
Cook cutlets on medium heat until golden brown on both sides.
Serve hot with mint chutney.
nutritionalBenefits: Good source of complex carbohydrates from oats, fiber from vegetables, and protein from besan. A satisfying snack that keeps hunger at bay.

title: Energy Balls (Evening Pre-Workout Snacks)
steps: Soak dates in warm water for 15 minutes. Drain.
In a food processor, blend dates, oats, chia seeds, peanut butter, cocoa powder, and cinnamon until it forms a sticky dough.
Roll into small balls.
Refrigerate for 30 minutes before serving.
Store in an airtight container in the refrigerator.
nutritionalBenefits: Natural sugars from dates provide quick energy, while oats and chia seeds offer sustained release. Protein from peanut butter supports muscle function.

title: Apple with Almond Butter (Evening Pre-Workout Snacks)
steps: Slice the apple.
Spread almond butter on apple slices or use as a dip.
Enjoy immediately.
nutritionalBenefits: Quick source of carbohydrates and fiber from apple, with protein and healthy fats from almond butter. A balanced pre-workout snack.

title: Coconut Water with Chia Seeds (Evening Pre-Workout Snacks)
steps: Mix chia seeds in coconut water and let it sit for 10 minutes.
Add lemon juice and a pinch of salt. Mix well.
Serve chilled.
nutritionalBenefits: Natural electrolytes from coconut water support hydration, while chia seeds provide omega-3 fatty acids and protein. Perfect for pre-workout hydration.

title: Paneer and Fruit Bowl (Post-Workout Snacks)
steps: In a bowl, mix paneer cubes and chopped fruits.
Drizzle honey if desired.
Sprinkle cinnamon powder.
Mix gently and enjoy.
nutritionalBenefits: High in protein from paneer, with carbohydrates from fruits for glycogen replenishment. A balanced post-workout snack.

title: Chickpea and Vegetable Salad (Post-Workout Snacks)
steps: In a bowl, mix chickpeas, cucumber, tomato, and bell pepper.
Add lemon juice, cumin powder, and salt. Mix well.
Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
Serve immediately.
nutritionalBenefits: Protein from chickpeas, with fiber and vitamins from vegetables. A refreshing and nutritious post-workout snack.

title: Yogurt with Honey and Nuts (Post-Workout Snacks)
steps: In a bowl, add yogurt.
Drizzle honey and sprinkle chopped nuts.
Add cinnamon powder.
Mix and enjoy.
nutritionalBenefits: Protein and probiotics from yogurt, with healthy fats from nuts. Supports muscle recovery and gut health.
